summary: This paper presents two novel peptide encoding methods based on physicochemical properties of amino acids, aiming to improve classification accuracy in machine learning applications. The effectiveness of these methods is demonstrated through extensive comparisons with existing encoding techniques across different classification problems, including HIV-protease inhibition, T-cell epitope recognition, and binding prediction for human leukocyte antigens.
formulas: Pp(20+k) = (1 / (M - k)) * sum(val(p, Aa) - val(p, Aa+k), a = 1 to M-k)
relationships: The effectiveness of peptide classification is dependent on the encoding method used, which transforms peptide sequences into a format suitable for machine learning classifiers.
The physicochemical properties of amino acids are crucial in determining the interaction between peptides and the human immune system, influencing the design of vaccines and treatments.

Different peptide encoding techniques influence the performance of classifiers, with novel methods proposed in this paper showing superior results compared to traditional methods like orthonormal encoding.
variables: M: Length of the peptide sequence
k: Specific position in the peptide sequence
val(p, Aa): Normalized value of the physicochemical property p for the amino acid at position Aa
EUC: Error under the ROC curve
AUC: Area under the ROC curve
key_ideas: Introduction of two novel encoding methods based on physicochemical properties of amino acids, which outperform traditional encoding methods in peptide classification tasks.
Extensive comparison of various encoding methods across multiple datasets to establish the most effective techniques for specific classification problems.
Demonstration of the importance of encoding techniques in the performance of machine learning classifiers, highlighting the potential for improved prediction accuracies in biomedical applications.
